text: The Persistent Expression of <extra_id_0> epsilony Globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - Deficient Mice Is Due to a Defect in the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - Gene - Silencing Mechanism in Definitive Erythroid Cells
Normally , the <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene is exclusively expressed in primitive erythrocytes and silenced in definitive erythrocytes .

To determine whether the persistent expression of <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is due to residual primitive erythrocytes or is due to ectopic expression of <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in definitive erythrocytes , we examined the spatial pattern of <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcripts in mouse embryos by in situ hybridization ( Figure 5 ) .
As expected , <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is not expressed in the WT 14.5-dpc liver , the site of definitive erythropoiesis in the fetus .
In contrast , abundant ectopic <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA expression is seen in the liver of 14.5-dpc mutants ( Figure 5 A-D ) .

However , the expression of <extra_id_0> betamaj <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> min globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is equally abundant in both WT and p100H mutant mice ( Figure 5 E and F ) .

These data demonstrate that the persistent high levels of <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are due to ectopic expression in the definitive erythroid cells that mature in the fetal liver , suggesting that there is an intrinsic defect of the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> silencing mechanism in <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - null mice .
